comments:
Version: 3.0.0
Build id: 200406192000
java -version at console reports build 1.4.2-b28.  1.5beta2 is also installed,
but with no public JRE.

I'm seeing a lot of issues with this build of Eclipse.  This particular problem
is 100% reproducible for me - it doesn't occur if no files are open when Eclipse
boots, with a single file open it occurs on boot, with two files open and focus
on the first it occurs on boot, with two files open and focus on the second it
occurs when selecting the first.  It doesn't occur on other editors, and always
occurs on the first.

A dialogue appears saying "An error has occurred.  See error log for more
details."  The tab displays a grey background with red text reading "An error
has occurred when creating this editor".  The log message is included at the end
of this report.

This exception is identical to that reported in bug 67730, but that report
changed focus and the original exception seems to have been dismissed.

Log follows:

Another error I'm seeing is likely to be related - and again this is 100%
reproducible.

After booting Eclipse without any editors open, opening the first editor causes
a dialogue to appear saying "Unable to create part:"  A second dialogue then
says "An error has occurred.  See error log for more details.".  The editor pane
appears displaying the same message as before ("An error has occurred when
creating this editor"), but without any title shown in the tab (literally just
square file icon, "X" close icon).

The error log contains two exceptions, as follows:

To ensure 1.4.2 is used pllease start eclipse.exe like this: eclipse.exe
-consoleLog -vmargs -showversion. Or do you already specify the VM by using the
-vm argument?

Did you install additional plug-ins (if so which ones) or copy 3.0 over an
existing release?

Cannot reproduce using 1.4.2 VM.

Probably related to bug 70002
Confirmed 1.4.2.  Those command line switches cause a VM exit and a dialogue
that lists C:\WINDOWS\java.exe as the vm - and that is definitely 1.4.2.

My Eclipse installation was made as follows:

1. Rename old C:\Program Files\eclipse folder as eclipse3m8.
2. Unzip eclipse-platform-SDK-3.0RC3-win32.zip to C:\Program Files\eclipse
3. Run Eclipse using a shortcut that runs '"C:\Program
Files\eclipse\eclipse.exe" -data C:\Development\Workspace'
4. Click Help > Software Updates > Find and Install
5. Select New features to install
6. Select update site
7. Select Java Development Tools and...

...But now I repeat the process, the 1.5 plugin isn't listed!

I apologise, I've been a little ill recently and my memory is a bit hazy.  I'm
pretty sure I got the 1.5 plugin through this process.  In fact, I'm
*reasonably* sure there was a second update site listed?

Has the 1.5 plugin been pulled from distribution?  Has an update site been taken
down, or was one up that shouldn't have been?  I'm now officially confused.  If
I can't get the 1.5 plugin installed, I can't replicate the environment I'm
seeing the bug in.


N.B. Yes, this process would have been easier if I'd downloaded the right zip in
the first place - but I never could work out which one I needed from the name
and have never found a document that explained it.  So I grabbed whatever I
could and auto-updated it. ;-)
Okay, more research: the features\org.eclipse.jdt.cheetah06_0.0.6\feature.xml
file in my previous RC3 install contains '<update label="%updateSiteName"
url="http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/jdt-core-home/update-site/"/>'.
 So there must have been another update site visible at the time I updated.  So
I've not completely lost it yet. :-)

However, I've looked at bug 70002, and have now replicated my reported error
without installing Cheetah:

1. Complete installation as described in previous comment (no Cheetah)
2. Close Eclipse
3. Delete everything from workspace, including .metadata tree
4. Load Eclipse
5. Close welcome screen
6. Open a new Perspective > Java
7. RMB > New > Project
8. Java Project > Next
9. "Test" > Finish
10. RMB > New > Class
11. "Test" > Finish

Dialogue: "Unable to create part:"
Dialogue: "An error has occurred.  See error log for more details."

Empty pane, no title in tab.  Grey background, red text.  This is the error I
listed in my first comment.

12. Close duff tab
13. Double click Test.java - editor opens correctly
14. Close Eclipse
15. Load Eclipse

Dialogue: "An error has occurred.  See error log for more details."

Empty pane, "Test.java" in tab.  Grey background, red text.  This is the error I
listed in the original report.

I suspect the reporter of 70002 will see the "first listed editor fails on open"
problem if they leave a file open and restart Eclipse.

Will attempt to attach log file:
Created an attachment (id=13289)
Error log
sorry, but from here:
>3. Delete everything from workspace, including .metadata tree
on, you're on your own: if you modify data in .metadata you're on your own.


*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 70002 ***
> sorry, but from here:
> > 3. Delete everything from workspace, including .metadata tree
> on, you're on your own: if you modify data in .metadata you're on your own.

Hmm, but how would that be different from just listing a different directory
with the -data command line switch?  I was rather under the impression that the
.metadata tree contained *only* data relevant to the current workspace -
otherwise how would multiple workspaces work at all?  Does the integrity of the
main installation depend on workspace-specific data?

Well, I'm pretty sure a clean install will behave exactly the same - I only
cleared out the .metadata tree to ensure that nothing strange was happening.  I
can confirm this if you like?
My misunderstanding: you deleted everything i.e. you cleaned the full workspace.
That's OK.
Ah, right - thanks for the clarification.

For a moment there I thought my multiple-workspace policy was flawed, and could
break at any time! ;-)
